msContents.summary: Grant deva-bhoga with the eigteen exemptions of the village of Uruvupalli to the temple of Viṣṇuhāradeva, built by the general Viṣṇuvarman, at Kaṇḍukūra, for the increase of life and force.

div.head: Plates
div.p:
1
jitaṃ bhagavatā śrī-vijaya-palakkaḍa-sthānāt parama-brahmaṇyasya sva
bāhu-balārjitorjita-kṣātra-tapo-nidheḥ vihita-sarvva-maryyādasya
sthiti-sthitasyāmitātmano mahārajasya śrī-skandavarmmaṇaḥ
prapautrasyārccita-śakti-siddhi-sampannasya pratāpopanata-rāja

trasya deva-dvija-guru-vṛddhopacāyino vivṛddha-vinayasyāneka-go-hi
raṇya-bhūmy-ādi-pradānaiḥ pravṛddha-dharmma-sañcayasya prajā-pālana
dakṣasya loka-pālānāṃ pañcamasya loka-pālasya satyātmano mahā

app.note: The word śrī could be considered a second auspicious opening formula (see translations in and in ), but it appears to be an honorific prefix to the issuing placename as in vijaya-śrī-palakkaḍa-sthānāt tfaPallava007 and śrīmad-vijaya-daśanapurādhiṣṭhānāt tfaPallava247.
The vowel i in rcci, which is postcript, is shows no inclusion of a repha.
The anusvāra in saṃ is above the next character.

Generally corrected by editiors to satya, but unnecessary. See Francis ****
This correction of the text appears unnecessary.
B lit keṇḍukūra qu’il corrige en kaṇḍukūra à cause des 2 occurrences qui suivent. Mais le texte est clairement kaṇḍukūra sur le FS.
Mais ce qui est lu d ne ressemble pas au ḍ de la ligne 1 (palakkaḍa).
The ā in tā is very slightly engraved due to the proximity of the binding hole.
The anusvāra at the end of °dattāṃ is above the next character.
That is, mayā + ādattā (“seized by me”), although the translation is correct (“J'ai émis”).

div.p: Update 1997 translation: (3b1-2=17-18) Etasmin grāmasīme dviśataṃ sima-nivarttanāni Dans les limites de ce village, se trouvent 200 nivartana >>> Dans les limites/le bornage du village, il y a en tout (sima-) deux cents nivartana. As we have sima and not sīma!

In , the numbering of plates is wrong. This edition was prepared with rubbings of Elliot's collection and Fleet was mislead by the fact that plate 1 recto and plate 5 verso, as they were blank were not rubbed. This was pointed to us by Andrew Grout of the Edinburgh University Library, where the plates are today kept.
On tad avagamya (line 28):comment on translation. See Francis.
Note the recurrent unstandard forms with diśi.
